title: Blue nevus with satellitosis: case report and literature review
patient:
A 15-year-old female patient presented to us with a pigmented lesion on the lateral
aspect of the left arm for 1 year, slowly enlarging and itchy over the past 2 months
(). Dermatological examination
revealed a brown-blue irregular, well defined macule, with approximately 8 mm, with
black-brown dots on the periphery ().
On dermoscopy, there was a black-brown lesion, in a homogenous pattern, composed of
structureless areas and with streaks in the periphery and satellite gray-blue
lesions (). Due to the suspicion of
melanoma, an excisional biopsy was performed. Histopathology revealed spindle-shaped
and dendritic, strongly pigmented melanocytes, amid dense fibrous stroma and
melanophages, predominantly occupying upper and mid dermis (). Satellite lesions were seen in the adjacent skin,
constituted by melanocytes similar to the central lesion, forming small aggregates
located close to the dermal vessels ().
The diagnosis was of common blue nevus with satellitosis.
